articles.headline: Sidestepping the Risk of a Privacy Breach
articles.snippet: If breaches are nearly inevitable for now, what are your odds of being swept up in all this, and how do you reduce them?
articles.abstract: If breaches are nearly inevitable for now, what are your odds of being swept up in all this, and how do you reduce them?
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, we reached the inevitable point in the controversy over the credit and debit card breaches where grim-faced retail executives from Target and Neiman Marcus, industry experts and consumer advocates turned up in Washington. They raised their hands and delivered well-rehearsed statements to our elected representatives.

articles.headline: Keeping Swindlers Out of Your Bank and Brokerage Accounts
articles.snippet: Beyond employing offline common sense, individuals need to be vigilant about how they use technology and the systems their advisers have to prevent their accounts from being hacked.
articles.abstract: Beyond employing offline common sense, individuals need to be vigilant about how they use technology and the systems their advisers have to prevent their accounts from being hacked.
articles.lead_paragraph: Data breaches at Target and Neiman Marcus were certainly scary. Personal information from tens of millions of people fell into the hands of cybercriminals.

articles.headline: Why Europe’s Job Picture Looks Different
articles.snippet: Unlike the United States labor force, Europe’s isn’t shrinking, and the working habits of older women are a major reason.
articles.abstract: Unlike the United States labor force, Europe’s isn’t shrinking, and the working habits of older women are a major reason.
articles.lead_paragraph: A theme often heard on this side of the Atlantic about the world’s Great Recession and its faltering recovery is how American policy has been more effective than Europe’s, which has been hitched to an expensive currency and shackled to a set of austere economic policies that served nobody but Germany.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico’s Second Cut to Junk Debt
articles.snippet: The new downgrade was expected to further narrow the island’s room for tight financial maneuvering and has reportedly given rise to discussions with lenders about short-term relief on certain payments.
articles.abstract: The new downgrade was expected to further narrow the island’s room for tight financial maneuvering and has reportedly given rise to discussions with lenders about short-term relief on certain payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | Moody’s Investors Service downgraded Puerto Rico’s general-obligation debt to junk status on Friday, intensifying a cash squeeze on the island and prompting some residents to blame hard-nosed creditors for their mounting troubles.

articles.headline: ‘Aid in Dying’ Movement Takes Hold in Some States
articles.snippet: Advocates of the practice, who shun the term “assisted suicide,” say they believe that as baby boomers watch frail parents suffer, support for their movement will grow further.
articles.abstract: Advocates of the practice, who shun the term “assisted suicide,” say they believe that as baby boomers watch frail parents suffer, support for their movement will grow further.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Helping the terminally ill end their lives, condemned for decades as immoral, is gaining traction. Banned everywhere but Oregon until 2008, it is now legal in five states. Its advocates, who have learned to shun the term “assisted suicide,” believe that as baby boomers watch frail parents suffer, support for what they call the “aid in dying” movement will grow further.

articles.headline: McDonald’s Opens in Vietnam, Bringing Big Mac to Fans of Banh Mi
articles.snippet: The fast-food giant is opening its first restaurant in the country, which some see as one of Asia’s last consumer markets with significant untapped potential.
articles.abstract: The fast-food giant is opening its first restaurant in the country, which some see as one of Asia’s last consumer markets with significant untapped potential.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — When Nguyen Hoang Anh and Nguyen Thi My Hao started dating, the 23-year-olds agreed to disagree about food: Mr. Anh adores Western-style fast food, but Ms. Hao mainly eats pho, a popular noodle soup, and other northern Vietnamese foods she has loved since childhood.

articles.headline: So Many Bribes, a Greek Official Can’t Recall Them All
articles.snippet: The testimony by a deputy in the Defense Ministry, if accurate, illustrates how arms makers from Germany, France, Sweden and Russia passed out payoffs to sell Greece weaponry that it could ill afford.
articles.abstract: The testimony by a deputy in the Defense Ministry, if accurate, illustrates how arms makers from Germany, France, Sweden and Russia passed out payoffs to sell Greece weaponry that it could ill afford.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — When Antonis Kantas, a deputy in the Defense Ministry here, spoke up against the purchase of expensive German-made tanks in 2001, a representative of the tank’s manufacturer stopped by his office to leave a satchel on his sofa. It contained 600,000 euros, about $814,000. Other arms manufacturers eager to make deals came by, too, some guiding him through the ins and outs of international banking and then paying him off with deposits to his overseas accounts.

articles.headline: Boehner Is Hit From the Right on Overhaul for Immigration
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner was under pressure from conservative groups on immigration, after he had defeated them on other issues.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner was under pressure from conservative groups on immigration, after he had defeated them on other issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As House Republicans embarked late last month in luxury buses for their retreat on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, their ears were already ringing with angry phone calls. Heritage Action, the political arm of the conservative Heritage Foundation, was imploring its members to flood the Capitol with warnings to accept “no amnesty.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Sounding the Tax Alarm, to Little Applause
articles.snippet: Whistle-blowers’ tips are pouring in to the I.R.S. But cash awards aren’t pouring out.
articles.abstract: Whistle-blowers’ tips are pouring in to the I.R.S. But cash awards aren’t pouring out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Renzo Gadola, a Swiss banker, and his client, an American physician, agreed to meet in the restaurant in the lobby of the Mandarin Oriental hotel in Miami. They talked amiably about tennis, a sport that each enjoyed, until the conversation took a serious turn.

articles.headline: Republicans Are Wooing the Wired
articles.snippet: In 2012, Democrats took a commanding lead in technological outreach to voters. Bruised Republicans are now trying to build their own bench — but in Silicon Valley, it’s not easy.
articles.abstract: In 2012, Democrats took a commanding lead in technological outreach to voters. Bruised Republicans are now trying to build their own bench — but in Silicon Valley, it’s not easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: At an after-hours hacking event at Microsoft’s headquarters in Redmond, Wash., Aaron Ginn approached an engineer whose face was buried in a laptop.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Economy and Crime Spur New Puerto Rican Exodus
articles.snippet: Puerto Rico’s extended woes, including high unemployment and pervasive crime, are causing a worrisome exodus of professionals and middle-class residents to places like Florida and Texas.
articles.abstract: Puerto Rico’s extended woes, including high unemployment and pervasive crime, are causing a worrisome exodus of professionals and middle-class residents to places like Florida and Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Alexis Sotomayor has many reasons to stay in Puerto Rico: his two children; his mother and their gossip sessions over plates of fried rice; and the balm of salt and sun that leavens his life on the island.

articles.headline: Nigeria Tries to ‘Sanitize’ Itself of Gays
articles.snippet: Since Nigeria’s president signed a law criminalizing homosexuality, arrests of gay people have multiplied and demands for a crackdown have flourished.
articles.abstract: Since Nigeria’s president signed a law criminalizing homosexuality, arrests of gay people have multiplied and demands for a crackdown have flourished.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAUCHI, Nigeria — The young man cried out as he was being whipped on the courtroom bench. The bailiff’s leather whip struck him 20 times, and when it was over, the man’s side and back were covered with bruises.

articles.headline: In the SAC Saga, It’s Hard to Chase a Shadow
articles.snippet: For traders at SAC Capital Advisors, it was another trial, another conviction. But its chief, Steven A. Cohen, remains out of range.
articles.abstract: For traders at SAC Capital Advisors, it was another trial, another conviction. But its chief, Steven A. Cohen, remains out of range.
articles.lead_paragraph: “How is the big guy?”
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Snowden Used Low-Cost Tool to Best N.S.A.
articles.snippet: Edward J. Snowden gathered National Security Agency secrets using cheap and widely available “web crawler” software, a breach that should have easily been detected, investigators say.
articles.abstract: Edward J. Snowden gathered National Security Agency secrets using cheap and widely available “web crawler” software, a breach that should have easily been detected, investigators say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officials investigating how Edward J. Snowden gained access to a huge trove of the country’s most highly classified documents say they have determined that he used inexpensive and widely available software to “scrape” the National Security Agency’s networks, and kept at it even after he was briefly challenged by agency officials.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: French Breakup Makes a Dinner Harder to Do
articles.snippet: President François Hollande of France will apparently be coming stag to a White House state dinner, which complicates more than just seating.
articles.abstract: President François Hollande of France will apparently be coming stag to a White House state dinner, which complicates more than just seating.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama invited President François Hollande of France for a state dinner, the White House drew up a list of 300 guests to honor the visiting leader and his partner, Valérie Trierweiler. Engraved invitations, with the presidential seal in gold at the top, were printed and set to be mailed.

articles.headline: Bill Keller, Former Editor of The Times, Is Leaving for News Nonprofit
articles.snippet: Mr. Keller, an Op-Ed columnist who was executive editor of The Times from 2003 to 2011, will be editor in chief of The Marshall Project, a nonprofit journalism start-up focused on the criminal justice system.
articles.abstract: Mr. Keller, an Op-Ed columnist who was executive editor of The Times from 2003 to 2011, will be editor in chief of The Marshall Project, a nonprofit journalism start-up focused on the criminal justice system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Keller, a columnist at The New York Times and its former executive editor, will leave the paper to become editor in chief of The Marshall Project, a nonprofit journalism start-up focused on the American criminal justice system.

articles.headline: Fight Over Minimum Wage Illustrates Web of Industry Ties
articles.snippet: The campaign against increasing the minimum wage illustrates how interest groups — conservative and liberal — are working in opaque ways to shape hot-button political debates.
articles.abstract: The campaign against increasing the minimum wage illustrates how interest groups — conservative and liberal — are working in opaque ways to shape hot-button political debates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just four blocks from the White House is the headquarters of the Employment Policies Institute, a widely quoted economic research center whose academic reports have repeatedly warned that increasing the minimum wage could be harmful, increasing poverty and unemployment.

articles.headline: ‘The New Normal’ for Tech Companies and Others: The Stealth I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Start-ups and much larger companies are taking increasing advantage of a 2012 law that allows them to file for public offerings while slowing the release of financial information.
articles.abstract: Start-ups and much larger companies are taking increasing advantage of a 2012 law that allows them to file for public offerings while slowing the release of financial information.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shhhh: A wave of tech start-ups are secretly seeking to go public.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Chastened G.O.P. Tries to Foil Insurgents at Primary Level
articles.snippet: The Republican Party establishment, concerned that unpredictable and unseasoned candidates have cost them seats in Congress, is trying to head off political hazards wherever it can.
articles.abstract: The Republican Party establishment, concerned that unpredictable and unseasoned candidates have cost them seats in Congress, is trying to head off political hazards wherever it can.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Richard H. Black is a Republican state senator from the Northern Virginia suburbs who once sent plastic fetuses to his colleagues with a note attached: “Would you kill this child?” He said a statue of Lincoln had no business going up in Richmond because it would be “sort of like putting the Confederate flag at the Lincoln Memorial.”

articles.headline: Local Papers Shine Light in Society’s Dark Corners
articles.snippet: Other news outlets did important work to advance news of the bridge scandal in New Jersey, but it’s hard to overstate the importance of local journalistic vigilance.
articles.abstract: Other news outlets did important work to advance news of the bridge scandal in New Jersey, but it’s hard to overstate the importance of local journalistic vigilance.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lot of important journalism begins with a simple, seemingly obvious question, like why traffic is snarled in New Jersey on the way into New York.

articles.headline: Break in Siege Is Little Relief to Syrian City
articles.snippet: Aid convoys were attacked during a three-day cease-fire in Homs, highlighting the difficulties plaguing even modest humanitarian efforts in Syria’s civil war.
articles.abstract: Aid convoys were attacked during a three-day cease-fire in Homs, highlighting the difficulties plaguing even modest humanitarian efforts in Syria’s civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — A three-day humanitarian cease-fire in the Syrian city of Homs was supposed to be a small breakthrough, a moment of relief for civilians trapped in a grim civil war.

articles.headline: Chinese Official Made Job Plea to JPMorgan Chase Chief
articles.snippet: Federal authorities are also investigating whether at least six other big banks hired applicants explicitly to win business from Chinese companies.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities are also investigating whether at least six other big banks hired applicants explicitly to win business from Chinese companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The executive suites of JPMorgan Chase in Midtown Manhattan may seem a world away from the politically connected Chinese job applicants who landed on the bank’s payroll.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Rival Shows Vie for Relevancy in Fashion Week
articles.snippet: In the extravaganza known as New York Fashion Week, it’s Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week versus MADE Fashion Week, an upstart rival.
articles.abstract: In the extravaganza known as New York Fashion Week, it’s Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week versus MADE Fashion Week, an upstart rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s Mercedes-Benz vs. Lexus, Maybelline vs. MAC, IMG vs. C.A.A.

articles.headline: Turkey Struggles to Protect Its Lira
articles.snippet: The frenzy of currency traders at Istanbul’s Grand Bazaar is a demonstration of how the value of Turkey’s money is determined largely by events beyond the country’s control.
articles.abstract: The frenzy of currency traders at Istanbul’s Grand Bazaar is a demonstration of how the value of Turkey’s money is determined largely by events beyond the country’s control.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — It was late afternoon in Istanbul. But seven time zones away, on Wall Street, the opening bell was ringing.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Sebnem Arsu

articles.headline: Wikipedia vs. the Small Screen
articles.snippet: Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia that depends on readers to create and edit its articles, is concerned about whether they will continue to do so on mobile devices.
articles.abstract: Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia that depends on readers to create and edit its articles, is concerned about whether they will continue to do so on mobile devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internet behemoths Google and Facebook have proved they can still attract users and advertisers as their traffic shifts from desktops to mobile devices.

articles.headline: Some Errors in Software at Exchange for Bitcoins
articles.snippet: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, said its problems had been caused by a previously undetected glitch in the basic Bitcoin protocol that made it possible for users to falsify transactions.
articles.abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, said its problems had been caused by a previously undetected glitch in the basic Bitcoin protocol that made it possible for users to falsify transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: What was once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, Mt. Gox, appeared near collapse on Monday, the latest symbol of the woes facing early players in the world of virtual currencies.
